page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

  +
[[File:Al jazeera 2011 egypt protests.ogv|thumb|An Al Jazeera report on the protests (in English)]]
  +
Thousands filled the streets across Egypt on Friday, 28 January,<ref name="Friday of Anger">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/be97d4a8-2b0b-11e0-a65f-00144feab49a.html#axzz1CMDTT7Ao|title=Pent-Up Anger Bursts on to Cairo Streets|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=28 January 2011|work=[[Financial Times]] }}</ref> called by some the "Friday of Anger" ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Ç§umÊ¿at al-Ä¡aá¸ab}}'' {{IPA-arz|ËgomÊet elËÉ£ÉdÉb<!--no [dË¤] in Egyptian Arabic-->|lang}})<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Andrew Sullivan|Sullivan, Andrew]]|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/01/awaiting-the-friday-of-anger.html|title=Awaiting the 'Friday Of Anger'|publisher=''[[The Daily Dish]]'' ([[blog]] of ''[[The Atlantic]]'')|date=|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> and by others as the "Day of Rage".<ref>Issacharoff, Avi (28 January 2011). [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/egypt-anti-government-protesters-declare-friday-day-of-rage-1.339629 "Egypt Anti-Government Protesters Declare Friday 'Day of Rage']. ''[[Haaretz]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41288680/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/ "Egypt Protesters, Police Brace for 'Day of Rage'"]. 27 January 2011. ''[[MSNBC]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref> Shortly before 1:00, hours ahead of the protests, the Egyptian government shut down Internet services,<ref name="aljazeera-272">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html|title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabist.net/blog/2011/1/28/urgent-egypt-has-shut-off-the-internet.html|title=Urgent: Egypt Has Shut Off the Internet|publisher=Arabist|last=El Amrani|first=Issandr|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=18 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/hack/2011/01/egypt-tor-use-skyrocketing-as.php|title=Egypt: Tor Use Skyrocketing as Users Route-Around Internet Blocks|work=[[ReadWriteWeb]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> although some people communicated using a [[text-to-speech]] telephone service set up by [[Google]] and [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessandleadership.com/technology/item/28137-google-twitter-launch-alte|title=Google, Twitter launch alternative service in Egypt |work=[[Business and Leadership]]|date=|accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> [[Text messaging]] and [[mobile phone]] services also appeared to be blocked.<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1&iref=BN1|title=Violent Clashes Erupt During Protests in Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> According to [[Vodafone]], all mobile operators in Egypt were instructed to suspend services in selected areas. The authorities had prior legislative approval to issue such an order.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/press.html|title=Press|publisher=[[Vodafone]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref>
Thousands filled the streets across Egypt on Friday, 28 January,<ref name="Friday of Anger">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/be97d4a8-2b0b-11e0-a65f-00144feab49a.html#axzz1CMDTT7Ao|title=Pent-Up Anger Bursts on to Cairo Streets|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=28 January 2011|work=[[Financial Times]] }}</ref> called by some the "Friday of Anger" ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Ç§umÊ¿at al-Ä¡aá¸ab}}'' {{IPA-arz|ËgomÊet elËÉ£ÉdÉb<!--no [dË¤] in Egyptian Arabic-->|lang}})<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Andrew Sullivan|Sullivan, Andrew]]|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/01/awaiting-the-friday-of-anger.html|title=Awaiting the 'Friday Of Anger'|publisher=''[[The Daily Dish]]'' ([[blog]] of ''[[The Atlantic]]'')|date=|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> and by others as the "Day of Rage".<ref>Issacharoff, Avi (28 January 2011). [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/egypt-anti-government-protesters-declare-friday-day-of-rage-1.339629 "Egypt Anti-Government Protesters Declare Friday 'Day of Rage']. ''[[Haaretz]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41288680/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/ "Egypt Protesters, Police Brace for 'Day of Rage'"]. 27 January 2011. ''[[MSNBC]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref> Shortly before 1:00, hours ahead of the protests, the Egyptian government shut down Internet services,<ref name="aljazeera-272">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html|title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabist.net/blog/2011/1/28/urgent-egypt-has-shut-off-the-internet.html|title=Urgent: Egypt Has Shut Off the Internet|publisher=Arabist|last=El Amrani|first=Issandr|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=18 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/hack/2011/01/egypt-tor-use-skyrocketing-as.php|title=Egypt: Tor Use Skyrocketing as Users Route-Around Internet Blocks|work=[[ReadWriteWeb]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> although some people communicated using a [[text-to-speech]] telephone service set up by [[Google]] and [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessandleadership.com/technology/item/28137-google-twitter-launch-alte|title=Google, Twitter launch alternative service in Egypt |work=[[Business and Leadership]]|date=|accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> [[Text messaging]] and [[mobile phone]] services also appeared to be blocked.<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1&iref=BN1|title=Violent Clashes Erupt During Protests in Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> According to [[Vodafone]], all mobile operators in Egypt were instructed to suspend services in selected areas. The authorities had prior legislative approval to issue such an order.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/press.html|title=Press|publisher=[[Vodafone]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Mohandeseen protests.jpg|thumb|left|The up-scale [[Mohandessin|Mohandeseen]] district in [[Giza]] during the Friday of Anger. Violent clashes occurred here between the protesters and the security forces which occupied the bridge on the left, involving stone-throwing, [[Molotov cocktails]], rubber bullets and tear gas grenades.]]
[[File:Mohandeseen protests.jpg|thumb|left|The up-scale [[Mohandessin|Mohandeseen]] district in [[Giza]] during the Friday of Anger. Violent clashes occurred here between the protesters and the security forces which occupied the bridge on the left, involving stone-throwing, [[Molotov cocktails]], rubber bullets and tear gas grenades.]]
Line 41: Line 42:
Shortly after [[Jumu'ah]] (Friday prayers), tens of thousands of Egyptians assembled to protest; within hours the number rose to hundreds of thousands. ElBaradei arrived from [[Giza]], where he had been leading protests, to Cairo,<ref name="ElBaradei to join Egypt protest">{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/ElBaradei-to-join-Egypt-protest-20110127|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w6N48d0H|archivedate=29 January 2011|title=ElBaradei To Join Egypt Protest|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[News24]]}}</ref><ref name="Mohamed ElBaradei: There's no going back">{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/27/elbaradei-return-cairo-egypt|title=Mohamed ElBaradei: There's No Going Back|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]] }}</ref> where he was placed under house arrest at a rally<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4020436,00.html|title=Report: ElBaradei Arrested in Egypt|work=[[Ynetnews]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/28/clashes-erupt-in-cairo-elbaradei-told-to-stay-put-cnn-camera-confiscated/| title=Unrest in Egypt: Mubarak Expected To Speak; Curfew Imposed in Major Cities| accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[CNN]]}}</ref> although he told [[Al Jazeera]] that he was unaware of his house arrest.<ref name="ajprotestersback">{{Cite news| url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112974149942894.html| title=Protesters Back on Egypt Streets| accessdate=29 January 2011| date=29 January 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera English}}</ref>
Shortly after [[Jumu'ah]] (Friday prayers), tens of thousands of Egyptians assembled to protest; within hours the number rose to hundreds of thousands. ElBaradei arrived from [[Giza]], where he had been leading protests, to Cairo,<ref name="ElBaradei to join Egypt protest">{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/ElBaradei-to-join-Egypt-protest-20110127|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w6N48d0H|archivedate=29 January 2011|title=ElBaradei To Join Egypt Protest|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[News24]]}}</ref><ref name="Mohamed ElBaradei: There's no going back">{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/27/elbaradei-return-cairo-egypt|title=Mohamed ElBaradei: There's No Going Back|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]] }}</ref> where he was placed under house arrest at a rally<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4020436,00.html|title=Report: ElBaradei Arrested in Egypt|work=[[Ynetnews]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/28/clashes-erupt-in-cairo-elbaradei-told-to-stay-put-cnn-camera-confiscated/| title=Unrest in Egypt: Mubarak Expected To Speak; Curfew Imposed in Major Cities| accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[CNN]]}}</ref> although he told [[Al Jazeera]] that he was unaware of his house arrest.<ref name="ajprotestersback">{{Cite news| url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112974149942894.html| title=Protesters Back on Egypt Streets| accessdate=29 January 2011| date=29 January 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera English}}</ref>
â   â
[[File:Al jazeera 2011 egypt protests.ogv|thumb|An Al Jazeera report on the protests (in English)]]
 
Throughout the day, police fired [[tear gas]], [[rubber bullets]], and [[water cannon]]s into crowds during violent clashes between authorities and protesters throughout Egypt.<ref name="cnn-crackdown">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html|title=Egypt Cracks Down on Mass Protests|work=[[CNN]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> Protestors in Suez took control of a police station, freed arrested protesters and then [[torched up|torched]] a nearby smaller local police post.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police Post|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]}}</ref><ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net">{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/28/friday-protests-liveblog|title=Live Blog â Egypt's Protests Erupt|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> In [[Port Said]] tens of thousands gathered and multiple government buildings were set ablaze.<ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net" /> In Suez, police shot and killed at least one protestor.<ref name="globemail" /> The government issued a 18:00 to 7:00 curfew, but protesters ignored it and were met by police.<ref name="globemail">{{Cite news| url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/egypt-protests-demand-mubaraks-ouster-army-imposes-curfew/article1886184/| title=Egypt Protests Demand Mubarak's Ouster; Army Imposes Curfew| accessdate=28 January 2011| date=28 January 2011| work=[[The Globe and Mail]]}}</ref> In the evening, one of the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] (NDP) headquarters buildings in Cairo<ref>''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' live broadcast, 16:23 UTC</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/#!/AJELive/status/31028059540819968|title=NDP's Headquarters Up in Flames|publisher=''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' (via [[Twitter]])|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> was set on fire by an unidentified culprit. While protesters paused for evening prayers, police continued firing tear gas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/#!/AJELive/status/31032922240716801|title=Tear Gas Canisters Were Fired|publisher=''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' (via [[Twitter]])|date=28 January 2011}}</ref>
Throughout the day, police fired [[tear gas]], [[rubber bullets]], and [[water cannon]]s into crowds during violent clashes between authorities and protesters throughout Egypt.<ref name="cnn-crackdown">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html|title=Egypt Cracks Down on Mass Protests|work=[[CNN]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> Protestors in Suez took control of a police station, freed arrested protesters and then [[torched up|torched]] a nearby smaller local police post.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police Post|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]}}</ref><ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net">{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/28/friday-protests-liveblog|title=Live Blog â Egypt's Protests Erupt|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> In [[Port Said]] tens of thousands gathered and multiple government buildings were set ablaze.<ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net" /> In Suez, police shot and killed at least one protestor.<ref name="globemail" /> The government issued a 18:00 to 7:00 curfew, but protesters ignored it and were met by police.<ref name="globemail">{{Cite news| url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/egypt-protests-demand-mubaraks-ouster-army-imposes-curfew/article1886184/| title=Egypt Protests Demand Mubarak's Ouster; Army Imposes Curfew| accessdate=28 January 2011| date=28 January 2011| work=[[The Globe and Mail]]}}</ref> In the evening, one of the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] (NDP) headquarters buildings in Cairo<ref>''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' live broadcast, 16:23 UTC</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/#!/AJELive/status/31028059540819968|title=NDP's Headquarters Up in Flames|publisher=''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' (via [[Twitter]])|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> was set on fire by an unidentified culprit. While protesters paused for evening prayers, police continued firing tear gas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/#!/AJELive/status/31032922240716801|title=Tear Gas Canisters Were Fired|publisher=''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' (via [[Twitter]])|date=28 January 2011}}</ref>
